blocks.text: Integration by the Resolution of a Product into a Sum.—A product cannot be integrated directly; but when the functions are trigonometric the product can be broken up into a sum of sine and cosine terms and therefore integrated.
\[ \int \sin^2 x \, dx = \int (1 - \cos^2 x) \, dx = x - \frac{1}{2} \int \cos(2x) \, dx \]

Integration by Substitution.—At times a substitution aids the integration; but the cases in which this method applies can only be distinguished after one has become pretty familiar with the differential of the denominator.

In this fraction it will be observed that the numerator is exactly the differential of the denominator. Hence if $u$ be written for the denominator, then there will be only the substitutions to apply.
